Questions.Question: According to the lesson, what was Sam's main problem with the original BookShelf codebase?
Options: The code was too slow to run
Database queries and business logic were tightly coupled throughout the codebase
Questions.Explanation: Sam's challenge showed that database queries were scattered throughout HTTP handlers and business logic was mixed with JSON serialization - making it impossible to add mobile apps or switch databases without rewriting everything.

Questions.Question: According to the lesson, in Hexagonal Architecture, your business logic should know about and directly depend on the database implementation.
Questions.Explanation: The core principle is that 'Your business logic should not know or care about the outside world.' The domain core is isolated from infrastructure concerns like databases.

Questions.Question: According to the course overview, which of the following can BookShelf support after applying Hexagonal Architecture? Select ALL that apply.
Options: Multiple interfaces (REST, GraphQL, gRPC, mobile apps)
Questions.Explanation: The lesson states BookShelf can support multiple interfaces, different databases, deploy anywhere (cloud, on-premise, embedded), and be tested independently. Only cloud deployment is incorrect - it can deploy anywhere.

Questions.Question: According to the hexagon diagram, the _______ Core sits at the center of the architecture, surrounded by adapters.
Questions.Explanation: The hexagon diagram shows the Domain Core (green) at the center, with Driving Adapters and Driven Adapters connecting it to the outside world.
